answers.answer: Its fairly reliable.  It can take up to 9 weeks to show positive, though, but many do develop antibodies sooner than that.If you have been vaccinated, that will show on this test.I'm not sure what you mean by too late?  Its never too late.AJ

Thanks for your reply AJ.  It didn't mention anything about being vaccinated just that surface was negative and that Hep B was negative. Maybe I should ask my doctor.  But most likely I was not vaccinated..I'm wondering if I was possibly infected 2 1/2 months ago, would it be too late to get the vaccination now?Also I understand that 95% that get this as an adult, develop antibodies and become immune.  Is this true?

I've not ever heard that, but hep b prevalence is very different in different countries.Because of vaccines, hep b is becoming far less common.And if you are negative thus far, it would be a good idea to talk to your doc about vaccination.If you have no antibodies, you haven't been vaccinated.AJ

Here from :http://www.hepb.org/patients/general_information.htm90% of healthy adults are able to "recover" by getting rid of the virus, which is confirmed by a blood test. Once a person has recovered, they are no longer contagious and are immune to future hepatitis B infections.andhttp://www.emedicinehealth.com/hepatitis_b/article_em.htmAbout 90-95% of people who are infected are able to fight off the virus so their infection never becomes chronic. Only about 5-10 percent of adults infected with HBV go on to develop chronic infection.I've also read it on cdc.gov but couldn't remember where i found it there.

Oh that doesn't mean that 90% will get it.  That means of those that are infected, 90% will be able to recover, and not have it become chronic.That means if you get it, there is a 10% chance that it would be chronic if you are otherwise healthy (as in no HIV, diabetes, or in some other way immunocompromised).Does that make sense?AJ
Thanks AJ.  So most peope who get this as an adult can overcome it?It's a little re-assuring...
Yes, only 10% will have it chronically, which for hep B, means longer than 6 months.You might be sicker than you've ever been, but most people do get rid of it.AJ

question: How reliable is a Hep B test at 34 days?  I'm not sure if I was ever vaccinated for Hep B... I plan on getting a 3 month test done to be sure but would it be too late to get at 2 1/2 months after possible exposure/infection?
title: Hep B question
